rsbNotes.title: Jer 46–51
rsbNotes.text: 46:1–51:64 This section of Jeremiah comprises a series of judgment oracles against the surrounding nations.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 50–51
rsbNotes.text: 50:1–51:64 The prophecy against Babylon (cf. Is. 13:1–14:23; 21:1–9) is the climax of the book. The previous prophecies have served Jeremiah’s purpose of showing that Babylon would prevail over “all the nations” (27:7) for a period. Babylon has appeared up to this point as the instrument of God’s wrath. Finally, however (as in 25:17–26), “the word of the Lord” is uttered against Babylon itself, to show that its own time of judgment must come (25:11, 12). The Hebrew text of Jeremiah has placed the prophecy (actually delivered in 593 b.c.; see 51:59 note) at this point in the book so that the judgment on Babylon may occupy the climactic position. The relative length of the prophecy also shows how important Babylon is in the theology of the book.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 51:58
rsbNotes.text:
51:58 high gates. The Ishtar Gate was known for its great height.

labor . . . the nations. The labor of subject nations in building Babylon’s fortifications will be of no use when God brings His judgment.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 51:59
rsbNotes.text:
51:59 Seraiah the son of Neriah. An official in Zedekiah’s administration, he was responsible for this expedition’s billeting en route. He is the brother of Baruch, Jeremiah’s scribe (32:12).

went with Zedekiah . . . to Babylon, in the fourth year of his reign. That is, in 593 b.c. The expedition may have been in response to a summons to explain Zedekiah’s part in the uprising against Nebuchadnezzar (27:3 note).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 51:60
rsbNotes.text: 51:60 a book. It may have contained the prophecies in chs. 50 and 51. See 36:2.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 51:63–64
rsbNotes.text: 51:63, 64 This final symbolic act (13:1–11 note) reinforced the last word of Jeremiah, that Babylon would fall.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 52
rsbNotes.text: 52:1–34 The final chapter of Jeremiah is an appendix describing the fall of Jerusalem and reminding the reader that Jeremiah’s prophecies were fulfilled. Despite its message of divine judgment for sin, the Book of Jeremiah ends (like 2 Kings) on a hopeful note by calling attention to the mercy shown to King Jehoiachin of Judah while in Babylonian exile (52:31–34; cf. 2 Kin. 25:27–30).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 52:1
rsbNotes.text: 52:1 Jeremiah of Libnah. Not Jeremiah the prophet, who was from Anathoth (1:1).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 52:12
rsbNotes.text: 52:12 the tenth day. 2 Kin. 25:8 has the “seventh day.” One or the other text could be a copyist’s error.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 52:22
rsbNotes.text: 52:22 five. 2 Kin. 25:17 has “three.” See note on v. 12.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 52:25
rsbNotes.text: 52:25 seven. 2 Kin. 25:19 has “five.” See note on v. 12.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 52:28–30
rsbNotes.text: 52:28–30 These verses refer to the two main deportations of Jews to Babylon, in 597 b.c. (“the seventh year”) and 586 b.c. (the “eighteenth year”; “nineteenth” in v. 12 is due to an alternate way of counting). A third, smaller deportation is also mentioned. The numbers here are smaller than those in 2 Kin. 24:14, 16, and may count only adult males.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 52:31
rsbNotes.text: 52:31 twenty-fifth. 2 Kin. 25:27 has “twenty-seventh.” See note on v. 12.
